1.text:
The Biography of a Grizzly
by

3.text:
Ernest Thompson Seton
Recording by Phil Chenevert

9.text:
Part I
The Cubhood of Wahb

12.text:
He was born over a score of years ago, away
up in the wildest part of the wild West, on

21.text:
the head of the Little Piney, above where
the Palette Ranch is now.

26.text:
His Mother was just an ordinary Silvertip,
living the quiet life that all Bears prefer,

32.text:
minding her own business and doing her duty
by her family, asking no favors of any one

37.text:
excepting to let her alone.
It was July before she took her remarkable

43.text:
family down the Little Piney to the Graybull,
and showed them what strawberries were, and

49.text:
where to find them.
Notwithstanding their Mother's deep conviction,

54.text:
the cubs were not remarkably big or bright;
yet they were a remarkable family, for there

60.text:
were four of them, and it is not often a Grizzly
Mother can boast of more than two.

67.text:
The woolly-coated little creatures were having
a fine time, and reveled in the lovely mountain

73.text:
summer and the abundance of good things. Their
Mother turned over each log and flat stone

79.text:
they came to, and the moment it was lifted
they all rushed under it like a lot of little

85.text: pigs to lick up the ants and grubs there hidden.

90.text:
It never once occurred to them that Mammy's
strength might fail sometime, and let the

95.text:
great rock drop just as they got under it;
nor would any one have thought so that might

101.text:
have chanced to see that huge arm and that
shoulder sliding about under the great yellow

107.text:
robe she wore. No, no; that arm could never
fail. The little ones were quite right. So

115.text:
they hustled and tumbled one another at each
fresh log in their haste to be first, and

121.text:
squealed little squeals, and growled little
growls, as if each was a pig, a pup, and a

127.text:
kitten all rolled into one.
They were well acquainted with the common

133.text:
little brown ants that harbor under logs in
the uplands, but now they came for the first

138.text:
time on one of the hills of the great, fat,
luscious Wood-ant, and they all crowded around

146.text:
to lick up those that ran out. But they soon
found that they were licking up more cactus-prickles

152.text:
and sand than ants, till their Mother said
in Grizzly, "Let me show you how."

160.text:
She knocked off the top of the hill, then
laid her great paw flat on it for a few moments,

166.text:
and as the angry ants swarmed on to it she
licked them up with one lick, and got a good

173.text:
rich mouthful to crunch without a grain of
sand or a cactus-stinger in it. The cubs soon

180.text:
learned. Each put up both his little brown
paws, so that there was a ring of paws all

186.text:
around the ant-hill, and there they sat, like
children playing "hands," and each licked

193.text:
first the right and then the left paw, or
one cuffed his brother's ears for licking

198.text:
a paw that was not his own, till the ant-hill
was cleared out and they were ready for a

206.text:
Ants are sour food and made the Bears thirsty,
so the old one led down to the river. After

212.text:
they had drunk as much as they wanted, and
dabbled their feet, they walked down the bank

218.text:
to a pool, where the old one's keen eye caught
sight of a number of Buffalo-fish basking

224.text:
on the bottom. The water was very low, mere
pebbly rapids between these deep holes, so

231.text:
Mammy said to the little ones:
"Now you all sit there on the bank and learn

239.text:
First she went to the lower end of the pool
and stirred up a cloud of mud which hung in

244.text:
the still water, and sent a long tail floating
like a curtain over the rapids just below.

251.text:
Then she went quietly round by land, and sprang
into the upper end of the pool with all the

257.text:
noise she could. The fish had crowded to that
end, but this sudden attack sent them off

264.text:
in a panic, and they dashed blindly into the
mud-cloud. Out of fifty fish there is always

271.text:
a good chance of some being fools, and half
a dozen of these dashed through the darkened

277.text:
water into the current, and before they knew
it they were struggling over the shingly shallow.

284.text:
The old Grizzly jerked them out to the bank,
and the little ones rushed noisily on these

290.text:
funny, short snakes that could not get away,
and gobbled and gorged till their little bellies

296.text:
looked like balloons.
They had eaten so much now, and the sun was

301.text:
so hot, that all were quite sleepy. So the
Mother-bear led them to a quiet little nook,

308.text:
and as soon as she lay down, though they were
puffing with heat, they all snuggled around

313.text:
her and went to sleep, with their little brown
paws curled in, and their little black noses

319.text:
tucked into their wool as though it were a
very cold day.

325.text:
After an hour or two they began to yawn and
stretch themselves, except little Fuzz, the

330.text:
smallest; she poked out her sharp nose for
a moment, then snuggled back between her Mother's

336.text:
great arms, for she was a gentle, petted little
thing. The largest, the one afterward known

343.text:
as Wahb, sprawled over on his back and began
to worry a root that stuck up, grumbling to

350.text:
himself as he chewed it, or slapped it with
his paw for not staying where he wanted it.

356.text:
Presently Mooney, the mischief, began tugging
at Frizzle's ears, and got his own well boxed.

364.text:
They clenched for a tussle; then, locked in
a tight, little grizzly yellow ball, they

369.text:
sprawled over and over on the grass, and,
before they knew it, down a bank, and away

374.text: out of sight toward the river.

378.text:
Almost immediately there was an outcry of
yells for help from the little wrestlers.

384.text:
There could be no mistaking the real terror
in their voices. Some dreadful danger was

389.text:
threatening.
Up jumped the gentle Mother, changed into

394.text:
a perfect demon, and over the bank in time
to see a huge Range-bull make a deadly charge

401.text:
at what he doubtless took for a yellow dog.
In a moment all would have been over with

407.text:
Frizzle, for he had missed his footing on
the bank; but there was a thumping of heavy

413.text:
feet, a roar that startled even the great
Bull, and, like a huge bounding ball of yellow

420.text:
fur, Mother Grizzly was upon him. Him! the
monarch of the herd, the master of all these

428.text:
plains, what had he to fear? He bellowed his
deep war-cry, and charged to pin the old one

436.text:
to the bank; but as he bent to tear her with
his shining horns, she dealt him a stunning

443.text:
blow, and before he could recover she was
on his shoulders, raking the flesh from his

450.text:
ribs with sweep after sweep of her terrific
claws.

455.text:
The Bull roared with rage, and plunged and
reared, dragging Mother Grizzly with him;

461.text:
then, as he hurled heavily off the slope,
she let go to save herself, and the Bull rolled

470.text:
This was a lucky thing for him, for the Grizzly
did not want to follow him there; so he waded

477.text:
out on the other side, and bellowing with
fury and pain, slunk off to join the herd

486.text:
Old Colonel Pickett, the cattle king, was
out riding the range. The night before, he

491.text:
had seen the new moon descending over the
white cone of Pickett's Peak.

495.text:
"I saw the last moon over Frank's Peak," said
he, "and the luck was against me for a month;

502.text:
now I reckon it's my turn."
Next morning his luck began. A letter came

508.text:
from Washington granting his request that
a post-office be established at his ranch,

514.text:
and contained the polite inquiry, "What name
do you suggest for the new post-office?"

521.text:
The Colonel took down his new rifle, a 45-90
repeater. "May as well," he said; "this is

529.text:
my month"; and he rode up the Graybull to
see how the cattle were doing.

536.text:
As he passed under the Rimrock Mountain he
heard a far-away roaring as of Bulls fighting,

542.text:
but thought nothing of it till he rounded
the point and saw on the flat below a lot

547.text:
of his cattle pawing the dust and bellowing
as they always do when they smell the blood

552.text:
of one of their number. He soon saw that the
great Bull, "the boss of the bunch," was covered

559.text:
with blood. His back and sides were torn as
by a Mountain-lion, and his head was battered

566.text:
as by another Bull.
"Grizzly," growled the Colonel, for he knew

571.text:
the mountains. He quickly noted the general
direction of the Bull's back trail, then rode

578.text:
toward a high bank that offered a view. This
was across the gravelly ford of the Graybull,

584.text:
near the mouth of the Piney. His horse splashed
through the cold water and began jerkily to

589.text:
climb the other bank.
As soon as the rider's head rose above the

594.text:
bank his hand grabbed the rifle, for there
in full sight were five Grizzly Bears, an

602.text:
old one and four cubs.
"Run for the woods," growled the Mother Grizzly,

608.text:
for she knew that men carried guns. Not that
she feared for herself; but the idea of such

615.text:
things among her darlings was too horrible
to think of. She set off to guide them to

621.text:
the timber-tangle on the Lower Piney. But
an awful, murderous fusillade began.

628.text:
_Bang!_ and Mother Grizzly felt a deadly pang.
_Bang!_ and poor little Fuzz rolled over with

636.text:
a scream of pain and lay still.
With a roar of hate and fury Mother Grizzly

642.text:
turned to attack the enemy.
_Bang!_ and she fell paralyzed and dying with

649.text:
a high shoulder shot. And the three little
cubs, not knowing what to do, ran back to

654.text:
their Mother.
_Bang! bang!_ and Mooney and Frizzle sank

660.text:
in dying agonies beside her, and Wahb, terrified
and stupefied, ran in a circle about them.

668.text:
Then, hardly knowing why, he turned and dashed
into the timber-tangle, and disappeared as

674.text:
a last _bang_ left him with a stinging pain
and a useless, broken hind paw.

683.text:
That is why the post-office was called Four-Bears.
The Colonel seemed pleased with what he had

689.text: done; indeed, he told of it himself.

692.text:
But away up in the woods of Anderson's Peak
that night a little lame Grizzly might have

699.text:
been seen wandering, limping along, leaving
a bloody spot each time he tried to set down

706.text:
his hind paw; whining and whimpering, "Mother!
Mother! Oh, Mother, where are you?" for he

712.text:
was cold and hungry, and had such a pain in
his foot. But there was no Mother to come

719.text:
to him, and he dared not go back where he
had left her, so he wandered aimlessly about

728.text:
Then he smelled some strange animal smell
and heard heavy footsteps; and not knowing

734.text:
what else to do, he climbed a tree. Presently
a band of great, long-necked, slim-legged

741.text:
animals, taller than his Mother, came by under
the tree. He had seen such once before and

748.text:
had not been afraid of them then, because
he had been with his Mother. But now he kept

753.text:
very quiet in the tree, and the big creatures
stopped picking the grass when they were near

759.text: him, and blowing their noses, ran out of sight.

763.text:
He stayed in the tree till near morning, and
then he was so stiff with cold that he could

769.text:
scarcely get down. But the warm sun came up,
and he felt better as he sought about for

775.text:
berries and ants, for he was very hungry.
Then he went back to the Piney and put his

781.text: wounded foot in the ice-cold water.

786.text:
He wanted to get back to the mountains again,
but still he felt he must go to where he had

791.text:
left his Mother and brothers. When the afternoon
grew warm, he went limping down the stream

798.text:
through the timber, and down on the banks
of the Graybull till he came to the place

803.text:
where yesterday they had had the fish-feast;
and he eagerly crunched the heads and remains

809.text:
that he found. But there was an odd and horrid
smell on the wind. It frightened him, and

817.text:
as he went down to where he last had seen
his Mother the smell grew worse. He peeped

822.text:
out cautiously at the place, and saw there
a lot of Coyotes, tearing at something. What

829.text:
it was he did not know; but he saw no Mother,
and the smell that sickened and terrified

835.text:
him was worse than ever, so he quietly turned
back toward the timber-tangle of the Lower

841.text:
Piney, and nevermore came back to look for
his lost family. He wanted his Mother as much

848.text:
as ever, but something told him it was no
use.

855.text:
As cold night came down, he missed her more
and more again, and he whimpered as he limped

861.text:
along, a miserable, lonely, little, motherless
Bear—not lost in the mountains, for he had

867.text:
no home to seek, but so sick and lonely, and
with such a pain in his foot and in his stomach

874.text:
a craving for the drink that would nevermore
be his. That night he found a hollow log,

880.text:
and crawling in, he tried to dream that his
Mother's great, furry arms were around him,

887.text: and he snuffled himself to sleep.

890.text:
Wahb had always been a gloomy little Bear;
and the string of misfortunes that came on

898.text:
him just as his mind was forming made him
more than ever sullen and morose.

905.text:
It seemed as though every one were against
him. He tried to keep out of sight in the

910.text:
upper woods of the Piney, seeking his food
by day and resting at night in the hollow

915.text:
log. But one evening he found it occupied
by a Porcupine as big as himself and as bad

922.text:
as a cactus-bush. Wahb could do nothing with
him. He had to give up the log and seek another

931.text:
One day he went down on the Graybull flat
to dig some roots that his Mother had taught

936.text:
him were good. But before he had well begun,
a grayish-looking animal came out of a hole

942.text:
in the ground and rushed at him, hissing and
growling. Wahb did not know it was a Badger,

949.text:
but he saw it was a fierce animal as big as
himself. He was sick, and lame too, so he

956.text:
limped away and never stopped till he was
on a ridge in the next cañon. Here a Coyote

962.text:
saw him, and came bounding after him, calling
at the same time to another to come and join

968.text:
the fun. Wahb was near a tree, so he scrambled
up to the branches. The Coyotes came bounding

975.text:
and yelping below, but their noses told them
that this was a young Grizzly they had chased,

981.text:
and they soon decided that a young Grizzly
in a tree means a Mother Grizzly not far away,

988.text: and they had better let him alone.

991.text:
After they had sneaked off Wahb came down
and returned to the Piney. There was better

997.text:
feeding on the Graybull, but every one seemed
against him there now that his loving guardian

1002.text:
was gone, while on the Piney he had peace
at least sometimes, and there were plenty

1009.text:
of trees that he could climb when an enemy
came.

1014.text:
His broken foot was a long time in healing;
indeed, it never got quite well. The wound

1021.text:
healed and the soreness wore off, but it left
a stiffness that gave him a slight limp, and

1027.text:
the sole-balls grew together quite unlike
those of the other foot. It particularly annoyed

1033.text:
him when he had to climb a tree or run fast
from his enemies; and of them he found no

1040.text:
end, though never once did a friend cross
his path. When he lost his Mother he lost

1047.text:
his best and only friend. She would have taught
him much that he had to learn by bitter experience,

1054.text:
and would have saved him from most of the
ills that befell him in his cubhood—ills

1059.text:
so many and so dire that but for his native
sturdiness he never could have passed through

1066.text:
The piñons bore plentifully that year, and
the winds began to shower down the ripe, rich

1075.text:
nuts. Life was becoming a little easier for
Wahb. He was gaining in health and strength,

1082.text:
and the creatures he daily met now let him
alone. But as he feasted on the piñons one

1089.text:
morning after a gale, a great Blackbear came
marching down the hill. "No one meets a friend

1096.text:
in the woods," was a byword that Wahb had
learned already. He swung up the nearest tree.

1103.text:
At first the Blackbear was scared, for he
smelled the smell of Grizzly; but when he

1108.text:
saw it was only a cub, he took courage and
came growling at Wahb. He could climb as well

1115.text:
as the little Grizzly, or better, and high
as Wahb went, the Blackbear followed, and

1121.text:
when Wahb got out on the smallest and highest
twig that would carry him, the Blackbear cruelly

1128.text:
shook him off, so that he was thrown to the
ground, bruised and shaken and half-stunned.

1133.text:
He limped away moaning, and the only thing
that kept the Blackbear from following him

1137.text:
up and perhaps killing him was the fear that
the old Grizzly might be about. So Wahb was

1145.text:
driven away down the creek from all the good
piñon woods.

1151.text:
There was not much food on the Graybull now.
The berries were nearly all gone; there were

1156.text:
no fish or ants to get, and Wahb, hurt, lonely,
and miserable, wandered on and on, till he

1164.text: was away down toward the Meteetsee.

1167.text:
A Coyote came bounding and barking through
the sage-brush after him. Wahb tried to run,

1174.text:
but it was no use; the Coyote was soon up
with him. Then with a sudden rush of desperate

1181.text:
courage Wahb turned and charged his foe. The
astonished Coyote gave a scared yowl or two,

1188.text:
and fled with his tail between his legs. Thus
Wahb learned that war is the price of peace.

1197.text:
But the forage was poor here; there were too
many cattle; and Wahb was making for a far-away

1203.text:
piñon woods in the Meteetsee Cañon when
he saw a man, just like the one he had seen

1209.text:
on that day of sorrow. At the same moment
he heard a _bang_, and some sage-brush rattled

1217.text:
and fell just over his back. All the dreadful
smells and dangers of that day came back to

1224.text:
his memory, and Wahb ran as he never had run
before.

1231.text:
He soon got into a gully and followed it into
the cañon. An opening between two cliffs

1237.text:
seemed to offer shelter, but as he ran toward
it a Range-cow came trotting between, shaking

1244.text:
her head at him and snorting threats against
his life.

1248.text:
He leaped aside upon a long log that led up
a bank, but at once a savage Bobcat appeared

1254.text:
on the other end and warned him to go back.
It was no time to quarrel. Bitterly Wahb felt

1261.text:
that the world was full of enemies. But he
turned and scrambled up a rocky bank into

1267.text:
the piñon woods that border the benches of
the Meteetsee.

1272.text:
The Pine Squirrels seemed to resent his coming,
and barked furiously. They were thinking about

1278.text:
their piñon-nuts. They knew that this Bear
was coming to steal their provisions, and

1285.text:
they followed him overhead to scold and abuse
him, with such an outcry that an enemy might

1291.text:
have followed him by their noise, which was
exactly what they intended.

1297.text:
There was no one following, but it made Wahb
uneasy and nervous. So he kept on till he

1304.text:
reached the timber line, where both food and
foes were scarce, and here on the edge of

1310.text:
the Mountain-sheep land at last he got a chance
to rest.

1317.text:
Wahb never was sweet-tempered like his baby
sister, and the persecutions by his numerous

1322.text:
foes were making him more and more sour. Why
could not they let him alone in his misery?

1330.text:
Why was every one against him? If only he
had his Mother back! If he could only have

1336.text:
killed that Blackbear that had driven him
from his woods! It did not occur to him that

1341.text:
some day he himself would be big. And that
spiteful Bobcat, that took advantage of him;

1349.text:
and the man that had tried to kill him. He
did not forget any of them, and he hated them

1356.text:
all.
Wahb found his new range fairly good, because

1362.text:
it was a good nut year. He learned just what
the Squirrels feared he would, for his nose

1368.text:
directed him to the little granaries where
they had stored up great quantities of nuts

1373.text:
for winter's use. It was hard on the Squirrels,
but it was good luck for Wahb, for the nuts

1380.text:
were delicious food. And when the days shortened
and the nights began to be frosty, he had

1385.text:
grown fat and well-favored.
He traveled over all parts of the cañon now,

1392.text:
living mostly in the higher woods, but coming
down at times to forage almost as far as the

1398.text:
river. One night as he wandered by the deep
water a peculiar smell reached his nose. It

1406.text:
was quite pleasant, so he followed it up to
the water's edge. It seemed to come from a

1412.text:
sunken log. As he reached over toward this,
there was a sudden _clank_, and one of his

1419.text: paws was caught in a strong, steel Beaver-trap.

1422.text:
Wahb yelled and jerked back with all his strength,
and tore up the stake that held the trap.

1429.text:
He tried to shake it off, then ran away through
the bushes trailing it. He tore at it with

1435.text:
his teeth; but there it hung, quiet, cold,
strong, and immovable. Every little while

1445.text:
he tore at it with his teeth and claws, or
beat it against the ground. He buried it in

1450.text:
the earth, then climbed a low tree, hoping
to leave it behind; but still it clung, biting

1456.text:
into his flesh. He made for his own woods,
and sat down to try to puzzle it out. He did

1462.text:
not know what it was, but his little green-brown
eyes glared with a mixture of pain, fright,

1470.text:
and fury as he tried to understand his new
enemy.

1474.text:
He lay down under the bushes, and, intent
on deliberately crushing the thing, he held

1479.text:
it down with one paw while he tightened his
teeth on the other end, and bearing down as

1486.text:
it slid away, the trap jaws opened and the
foot was free. It was mere chance, of course,

1492.text:
that led him to squeeze both springs at once.
He did not understand it, but he did not forget

1498.text:
it, and he got these not very clear ideas:
"There is a dreadful little enemy that hides

1506.text:
by the water and waits for one. It has an
odd smell. It bites one's paws and is too

1512.text:
hard for one to bite. But it can be got off
by hard squeezing."

1519.text:
For a week or more the little Grizzly had
another sore paw, but it was not very bad

1524.text: if he did not do any climbing.

1527.text:
It was now the season when the Elk were bugling
on the mountains. Wahb heard them all night,

1533.text:
and once or twice had to climb to get away
from one of the big-antlered Bulls. It was

1539.text:
also the season when the trappers were coming
into the mountains, and the Wild Geese were

1544.text:
honking overhead. There were several quite
new smells in the woods, too. Wahb followed

1551.text:
one of these up, and it led to a place where
were some small logs piled together; then,

1556.text:
mixed with the smell that had drawn him, was
one that he hated—he remembered it from

1562.text:
the time when he had lost his Mother. He sniffed
about carefully, for it was not very strong,

1569.text:
and learned that this hateful smell was on
a log in front, and the sweet smell that made

1576.text:
his mouth water was under some brush behind.
So he went around, pulled away the brush till

1582.text:
he got the prize, a piece of meat, and as
he grabbed it, the log in front went down

1587.text:
with a heavy _chock_.
It made Wahb jump; but he got away all right

1594.text:
with the meat and some new ideas, and with
one old idea made stronger, and that was,

1601.text:
"When that hateful smell is around it always
means trouble."

1608.text:
As the weather grew colder, Wahb became very
sleepy; he slept all day when it was frosty.

1615.text:
He had not any fixed place to sleep in; he
knew a number of dry ledges for sunny weather,

1621.text:
and one or two sheltered nooks for stormy
days. He had a very comfortable nest under

1626.text:
a root, and one day, as it began to blow and
snow, he crawled into this and curled up to

1633.text:
sleep. The storm howled without. The snow
fell deeper and deeper. It draped the pine-trees

1640.text:
till they bowed, then shook themselves clear
to be draped anew. It drifted over the mountains

1647.text:
and poured down the funnel-like ravines, blowing
off the peaks and ridges, and filling up the

1652.text:
hollows level with their rims. It piled up
over Wahb's den, shutting out the cold of

1658.text:
the winter, shutting out itself: and Wahb
slept and slept.

1666.text:
He slept all winter without waking, for such
is the way of Bears, and yet when spring came

1672.text:
and aroused him, he knew that he had been
asleep a long time. He was not much changed—he

1680.text:
had grown in height, and yet was but little
thinner. He was now very hungry, and forcing

1687.text:
his way through the deep drift that still
lay over his den, he set out to look for food.

1694.text:
There were no piñon-nuts to get, and no berries
or ants; but Wahb's nose led him away up the

1701.text:
cañon to the body of a winter-killed Elk,
where he had a fine feast, and then buried

1709.text:
Day after day he came back till he had finished
it. Food was very scarce for a couple of months,

1717.text:
and after the Elk was eaten, Wahb lost all
the fat he had when he awoke. One day he climbed

1724.text:
over the Divide into the Warhouse Valley.
It was warm and sunny there, vegetation was

1730.text:
well advanced, and he found good forage. He
wandered down toward the thick timber, and

1736.text:
soon smelled the smell of another Grizzly.
This grew stronger and led him to a single

1742.text:
tree by a Bear-trail. Wahb reared up on his
hind feet to smell this tree. It was strong

1749.text:
of Bear, and was plastered with mud and Grizzly
hair far higher than he could reach; and Wahb

1755.text:
knew that it must have been a very large Bear
that had rubbed himself there. He felt uneasy.

1762.text:
He used to long to meet one of his own kind,
yet now that there was a chance of it he was

1768.text:
filled with dread.
No one had shown him anything but hatred in

1773.text:
his lonely, unprotected life, and he could
not tell what this older Bear might do. As

1779.text:
he stood in doubt, he caught sight of the
old Grizzly himself slouching along a hillside,

1786.text:
stopping from time to time to dig up the quamash-roots
and wild turnips.

1791.text:
He was a monster. Wahb instinctively distrusted
him, and sneaked away through the woods and

1799.text:
up a rocky bluff where he could watch.
Then the big fellow came on Wahb's track and

1805.text:
rumbled a deep growl of anger; he followed
the trail to the tree, and rearing up, he

1811.text:
tore the bark with his claws, far above where
Wahb had reached. Then he strode rapidly along

1818.text:
Wahb's trail. But the cub had seen enough.
He fled back over the Divide into the Meteetsee

1826.text:
Cañon, and realized in his dim, bearish way

1832.text:
was so poor.
As the summer came on, his coat was shed.

1838.text:
His skin got very itchy, and he found pleasure
in rolling in the mud and scraping his back

1843.text:
against some convenient tree. He never climbed
now: his claws were too long, and his arms,

1850.text:
though growing big and strong, were losing
that suppleness of wrist that makes cub Grizzlies

1856.text:
and all Blackbears great climbers. He now
dropped naturally into the Bear habit of seeing

1863.text:
how high he could reach with his nose on the
rubbing-post, whenever he was near one.

1868.text:
He may not have noticed it, yet each time
he came to a post, after a week or two away,

1875.text:
he could reach higher, for Wahb was growing
fast and coming into his strength.

1881.text:
Sometimes he was at one end of the country
that he felt was his, and sometimes at another,

1886.text:
but he had frequent use for the rubbing-tree,
and thus it was that his range was mapped

1892.text:
out by posts with his own mark on them.
One day late in summer he sighted a stranger

1899.text:
on his land, a glossy Blackbear, and he felt
furious against the interloper. As the Blackbear

1906.text:
came nearer Wahb noticed the tan-red face,
the white spot on his breast, and then the

1913.text:
bit out of his ear, and last of all the wind
brought a whiff. There could be no further

1919.text:
doubt it was the very smell: this was the
black coward that had chased him down the

1925.text:
Piney long ago. But how he had shrunken! Before,
he had looked like a giant; now Wahb felt

1933.text:
he could crush him with one paw. Revenge is
sweet, Wahb felt, though he did not exactly

1940.text:
say it, and he went for that red-nosed Bear.
But the Black one went up a small tree like

1946.text:
a Squirrel. Wahb tried to follow as the other
once followed him, but somehow he could not.

1953.text:
He did not seem to know how to take hold now,
and after a while he gave it up and went away,

1960.text:
although the Blackbear brought him back more
than once by coughing in derision. Later on

1966.text:
that day, when the Grizzly passed again, the
red-nosed one had gone.

1972.text:
As the summer waned, the upper forage-grounds
began to give out, and Wahb ventured down

1978.text:
to the Lower Meteetsee one night to explore.
There was a pleasant odor on the breeze, and

1984.text:
following it up, Wahb came to the carcass
of a Steer. A good distance away from it were

1990.text:
some tiny Coyotes, mere dwarfs compared with
those he remembered. Right by the carcass

1996.text:
was another that jumped about in the moonlight
in a foolish way. For some strange reason

2002.text:
it seemed unable to get away. Wahb's old hatred
broke out. He rushed up. In a flash the Coyote

2010.text:
bit him several times before, with one blow
of that great paw, Wahb smashed him into a

2016.text:
limp, furry rag; then broke in all his ribs
with a crunch or two of his jaws. Oh, but

2023.text:
it was good to feel the hot, bloody juices
oozing between his teeth!

2029.text:
The Coyote was caught in a trap. Wahb hated
the smell of the iron, so he went to the other

2035.text:
side of the carcass, where it was not so strong,
and had eaten but little before _clank_, and

2041.text:
his foot was caught in a Wolf-trap that he
had not seen.

2046.text:
But he remembered that he had once before
been caught and had escaped by squeezing the

2052.text:
trap. He set a hind foot on each spring and
pressed till the trap opened and released

2059.text:
his paw. About the carcass was the smell that
he knew stood for man, so he left it and wandered

2066.text:
down-stream; but more and more often he got
whiffs of that horrible odor, so he turned

2073.text: and went back to his quiet piñon benches.

2087.text:
Wahb's third summer had brought him the stature
of a large-sized Bear, though not nearly the

2093.text:
bulk and power that in time were his. He was
very light-colored now, and this was why Spahwat,

2099.text:
a Shoshone Indian who more than once hunted
him, called him the Whitebear, or Wahb.

2107.text:
Spahwat was a good hunter, and as soon as
he saw the rubbing-tree on the Upper Meteetsee

2112.text:
he knew that he was on the range of a big
Grizzly. He bushwhacked the whole valley,

2118.text:
and spent many days before he found a chance
to shoot; then Wahb got a stinging flesh-wound

2124.text:
in the shoulder. He growled horribly, but
it had seemed to take the fight out of him;

2130.text:
he scrambled up the valley and over the lower
hills till he reached a quiet haunt, where

2137.text:
His knowledge of healing was wholly instinctive.
He licked the wound and all around it, and

2143.text:
sought to be quiet. The licking removed the
dirt, and by massage reduced the inflammation,

2149.text:
and it plastered the hair down as a sort of
dressing over the wound to keep out the air,

2155.text:
dirt, and microbes. There could be no better
treatment.

2160.text:
But the Indian was on his trail. Before long
the smell warned Wahb that a foe was coming,

2168.text:
so he quietly climbed farther up the mountain
to another resting-place. But again he sensed

2174.text:
the Indian's approach, and made off. Several
times this happened, and at length there was

2179.text:
a second shot and another galling wound. Wahb
was furious now. There was nothing that really

2186.text:
frightened him but that horrible odor of man,
iron, and guns, that he remembered from the

2192.text:
day when he lost his Mother; but now all fear
of these left him. He heaved painfully up

2199.text:
the mountain again, and along under a six-foot
ledge, then up and back to the top of the

2205.text:
bank, where he lay flat. On came the Indian,
armed with knife and gun; deftly, swiftly

2213.text:
keeping on the trail; gloating joyfully over
each bloody print that meant such anguish

2219.text:
to the hunted Bear. Straight up the slide
of broken rock he came, where Wahb, ferocious

2225.text:
with pain, was waiting on the ledge. On sneaked
the dogged hunter; his eye still scanned the

2232.text:
bloody slots or swept the woods ahead, but
never was raised to glance above the ledge.

2238.text:
And Wahb, as he saw this shape of Death relentless
on his track, and smelled the hated smell,

2246.text:
poised his bulk at heavy cost upon his quivering,
mangled arm, there held until the proper instant

2253.text:
came, then to his sound arm's matchless native
force he added all the weight of desperate

2260.text:
hate as down he struck one fearful, crushing
blow. The Indian sank without a cry, and then

2269.text:
dropped out of sight. Wahb rose, and sought
again a quiet nook where he might nurse his

2277.text:
wounds. Thus he learned that one must fight
for peace; for he never saw that Indian again,

2284.text: and he had time to rest and recover.

2289.text:
The years went on as before, except that each
winter Wahb slept less soundly, and each spring

2296.text:
he came out earlier and was a bigger Grizzly,
with fewer enemies that dared to face him.

2302.text:
When his sixth year came he was a very big,
strong, sullen Bear, with neither friendship

2310.text:
nor love in his life since that evil day on
the Lower Piney.

2316.text:
No one ever heard of Wahb's mate. No one believes
that he ever had one. The love-season of Bears

2322.text:
came and went year after year, but left him
alone in his prime as he had been in his youth.

2330.text:
It is not good for a Bear to be alone; it
is bad for him in every way. His habitual

2337.text:
moroseness grew with his strength, and any
one chancing to meet him now would have called

2345.text:
He had lived in the Meteetsee Valley since
first he betook himself there, and his character

2351.text:
had been shaped by many little adventures
with traps and his wild rivals of the mountains.

2357.text:
But there was none of the latter that he now
feared and he knew enough to avoid the first,

2363.text:
for that penetrating odor of man and iron
was a never-failing warning, especially after

2370.text:
an experience which befell him in his sixth
year.

2374.text:
His ever-reliable nose told him that there
was a dead Elk down among the timber.

2382.text:
He went up the wind, and there, sure enough,
was the great delicious carcass, already torn

2388.text:
open at the very best place. True, there was
that terrible man-and-iron taint, but it was

2395.text:
so slight and the feast so tempting that after
circling around and inspecting the carcass

2401.text:
from his eight feet of stature, as he stood
erect, he went cautiously forward, and at

2407.text:
once was caught by his left paw in an enormous
Bear-trap. He roared with pain and slashed

2415.text:
about in a fury. But this was no Beaver-trap;
it was a big forty-pound Bear-catcher, and

2427.text:
Wahb fairly foamed with rage, and madly grit
his teeth upon the trap. Then he remembered

2433.text:
his former experiences. He placed the trap
between his hind legs, with a hind paw on

2440.text:
each spring, and pressed down with all his
weight. But it was not enough. He dragged

2447.text:
off the trap and its clog, and went clanking
up the mountain. Again and again he tried

2453.text:
to free his foot, but in vain, till he came
where a great trunk crossed the trail a few

2459.text:
feet from the ground. By chance, or happy
thought, he reared again under this and made

2465.text:
a new attempt. With a hind foot on each spring
and his mighty shoulders underneath the tree,

2473.text:
he bore down with his titanic strength: the
great steel springs gave way, the jaws relaxed,

2480.text:
and he tore out his foot. So Wahb was free
again, though he left behind a great toe which

2488.text:
had been nearly severed by the first snap
of the steel.

2493.text:
Again Wahb had a painful wound to nurse, and
as he was a left-handed Bear,—that is, when

2500.text:
he wished to turn a rock over he stood on
the right paw and turned with the left,—one

2505.text:
result of this disablement was to rob him
for a time of all those dainty foods that

2511.text:
are found under rocks or logs. The wound healed
at last, but he never forgot that experience,

2519.text:
and thenceforth the pungent smell of man and
iron, even without the gun smell, never failed

2526.text:
to enrage him.
Many experiences had taught him that it is

2532.text:
better to run if he only smelled the hunter
or heard him far away, but to fight desperately

2539.text:
if the man was close at hand. And the cow-boys
soon came to know that the Upper Meteetsee

2545.text:
was the range of a Bear that was better let
alone.

2551.text:
One day after a long absence Wahb came into
the lower part of his range, and saw to his

2558.text:
surprise one of the wooden dens that men make
for themselves. As he came around to get the

2565.text:
wind, he sensed the taint that never failed
to infuriate him now, and a moment later he

2572.text:
heard a loud _bang_ and felt a stinging shock
in his left hind leg, the old stiff leg. He

2581.text:
wheeled about, in time to see a man running
toward the new-made shanty. Had the shot been

2587.text:
in his shoulder Wahb would have been helpless,
but it was not.

2593.text:
Mighty arms that could toss pine logs like
broomsticks, paws that with one tap could

2599.text:
crush the biggest Bull upon the range, claws
that could tear huge slabs of rock from the

2606.text:
mountain-side—what was even the deadly rifle
to them!

2611.text:
When the man's partner came home that night
he found him on the reddened shanty floor.

2617.text:
The bloody trail from outside and a shaky,
scribbled note on the back of a paper novel

2622.text:
told the tale.
It was Wahb done it. I seen him by the spring

2627.text:
and wounded him. I tried to git on the shanty,
but he ketched me. My God, how I suffer!

2636.text:
It was all fair. The man had invaded the Bear's
country, had tried to take the Bear's life,

2642.text:
and had lost his own. But Jack's partner swore
he would kill that Bear.

2648.text:
He took up the trail and followed it up the
cañon, and there bushwhacked and hunted day

2655.text:
after day. He put out baits and traps, and
at length one day he heard a _crash_, _clatter_,

2662.text:
_thump_, and a huge rock bounded down a bank
into a wood, scaring out a couple of deer

2668.text:
that floated away like thistle-down. Miller
thought at first that it was a land-slide;

2675.text:
but he soon knew that it was Wahb that had
rolled the boulder over merely for the sake

2680.text: of two or three ants beneath it.

2683.text:
The wind had not betrayed him, so on peering
through the bush Miller saw the great Bear

2689.text:
as he fed, favoring his left hind leg and
growling sullenly to himself at a fresh twinge

2696.text:
of pain. Miller steadied himself, and thought,
"Here goes a finisher or a dead miss." He

2703.text:
gave a sharp whistle, the Bear stopped every
move, and, as he stood with ears acock, the

2710.text:
man fired at his head.
But at that moment the great shaggy head moved,

2716.text:
only an infuriating scratch was given, the
smoke betrayed the man's place, and the Grizzly

2723.text:
made savage, three-legged haste to catch his
foe.

2728.text:
Miller dropped his gun and swung lightly into
a tree, the only large one near. Wahb raged

2734.text:
in vain against the trunk. He tore off the
bark with his teeth and claws; but Miller

2741.text:
was safe beyond his reach. For fully four
hours the Grizzly watched, then gave it up,

2748.text:
and slowly went off into the bushes till lost
to view. Miller watched him from the tree,

2755.text:
and afterward waited nearly an hour to be
sure that the Bear was gone. He then slipped

2760.text:
to the ground, got his gun, and set out for
camp. But Wahb was cunning; he had only _seemed_

2769.text:
to go away, and then had sneaked back quietly
to watch. As soon as the man was away from

2776.text:
the tree, too far to return, Wahb dashed after
him. In spite of his wounds the Bear could

2783.text:
move the faster. Within a quarter of a mile—well,
Wahb did just what the man had sworn to do

2791.text:
to him.
Long afterward his friends found the gun and

2796.text:
enough to tell the tale.
The claim-shanty on the Meteetsee fell to

2801.text:
pieces. It never again was used, for no man
cared to enter a country that had but few

2807.text:
allurements to offset its evident curse of
ill luck, and where such a terrible Grizzly

2815.text:
Then they found good gold on the Upper Meteetsee.
Miners came in pairs and wandered through

2823.text:
the peaks, rooting up the ground and spoiling
the little streams—grizzly old men mostly,

2830.text:
that had lived their lives in the mountain
and were themselves slowly turning into Grizzly

2835.text:
Bears; digging and grubbing everywhere, not
for good, wholesome roots, but for that shiny

2841.text:
yellow sand that they could not eat; living
the lives of Grizzlies, asking nothing but

2847.text: to be let alone to dig.

2850.text:
They seemed to understand Grizzly Wahb. The
first time they met, Wahb reared up on his

2857.text:
hind legs, and the wicked green lightnings
began to twinkle in his small eyes. The elder

2863.text:
man said to his mate:
"Let him alone, and he won't bother you."

2868.text:
"Ain't he an awful size, though?" replied
the other, nervously.

2875.text:
Wahb was about to charge, but something held
him back—a something that had no reference

2881.text:
to his senses, that was felt only when they
were still; a something that in Bear and Man

2888.text:
is wiser than his wisdom, and that points
the way at every doubtful fork in the dim

2896.text:
Of course Wahb did not understand what the
men said, but he did feel that there was something

2902.text:
different here. The smell of man and iron
was there, but not of that maddening kind,

2910.text:
and he missed the pungent odor that even yet
brought back the dark days of his cubhood.

2916.text:
The men did not move, so Wahb rumbled a subterranean
growl, dropped down on his four feet, and

2923.text:
went on.
Late the same year Wahb ran across the red-nosed

2929.text:
Blackbear. How that Bear did keep on shrinking!
Wahb could have hurled him across the Graybull

2938.text:
But the Blackbear did not mean to let him
try. He hustled his fat, podgy body up a tree

2945.text:
at a rate that made him puff. Wahb reached
up nine feet from the ground, and with one

2951.text:
rake of his huge claws tore off the bark clear
to the shining white wood and down nearly

2958.text:
to the ground; and the Blackbear shivered
and whimpered with terror as the scraping

2963.text:
of those awful claws ran up the trunk and
up his spine in a way that was horribly suggestive.

2973.text:
What was it that the sight of that Blackbear
stirred in Wahb? Was it memories of the Upper

2978.text:
Piney, long forgotten; thoughts of a woodland
rich in food?

2984.text:
Wahb left him trembling up there as high as
he could get, and without any very clear purpose

2990.text:
swung along the upper benches of the Meteetsee
down to the Graybull, around the foot of the

2996.text:
Rimrock Mountain; on, till hours later he
found himself in the timber-tangle of the

3003.text:
Lower Piney, and among the berries and ants
of the old times.

3008.text:
He had forgotten what a fine land the Piney
was: plenty of food, no miners to spoil the

3015.text:
streams, no hunters to keep an eye on, and
no mosquitoes or flies, but plenty of open,

3021.text:
sunny glades and sheltering woods, backed
up by high, straight cliffs to turn the colder

3027.text:
winds.
There were, moreover, no resident Grizzlies,

3032.text:
no signs even of passing travelers, and the
Blackbears that were in possession did not

3038.text:
count.
Wahb was well pleased. He rolled his vast

3044.text:
bulk in an old Buffalo-wallow, and rearing
up against a tree where the Piney Cañon quits

3050.text:
the Graybull Cañon, he left on it his mark
fully eight feet from the ground.

3057.text:
In the days that followed he wandered farther
and farther up among the rugged spurs of the

3062.text:
Shoshones, and took possession as he went.
He found the sign-boards of several Blackbears,

3069.text:
and if they were small dead trees he sent
them crashing to earth with a drive of his

3075.text:
giant paw. If they were green, he put his
own mark over the other mark, and made it

3081.text:
clearer by slashing the bark with the great
pickaxes that grew on his toes.

3088.text:
The Upper Piney had so long been a Blackbear
range that the Squirrels had ceased storing

3094.text:
their harvest in hollow trees, and were now
using the spaces under flat rocks, where the

3099.text:
Blackbears could not get at them; so Wahb
found this a land of plenty: every fourth

3105.text:
or fifth rock in the pine woods was the roof
of a Squirrel or Chipmunk granary, and when

3111.text:
he turned it over, if the little owner were
there, Wahb did not scruple to flatten him

3117.text:
with his paw and devour him as an agreeable
relish to his own provisions.

3123.text:
And wherever Wahb went he put up his sign-board:
Trespassers beware!

3131.text:
It was written on the trees as high up as
he could reach, and every one that came by

3137.text:
understood that the scent of it and the hair
in it were those of the great Grizzly Wahb.

3145.text:
If his Mother had lived to train him, Wahb
would have known that a good range in spring

3150.text:
may be a bad one in summer. Wahb found out
by years of experience that a total change

3156.text:
with the seasons is best. In the early spring
the Cattle and Elk ranges, with their winter-killed

3162.text:
carcasses, offer a bountiful feast. In early
summer the best forage is on the warm hillsides

3170.text:
where the quamash and the Indian turnip grow.
In late summer the berry-bushes along the

3175.text:
river-flat are laden with fruit, and in autumn
the pine woods gave good chances to fatten

3181.text:
for the winter. So he added to his range each
year. He not only cleared out the Blackbears

3188.text:
from the Piney and the Meteetsee, but he went
over the Divide and killed that old fellow

3193.text:
that had once chased him out of the Warhouse
Valley. And, more than that, he held what

3200.text:
he had won, for he broke up a camp of tenderfeet
that were looking for a ranch location on

3205.text:
the Middle Meteetsee; he stampeded their horses,
and made general smash of the camp. And so

3212.text:
all the animals, including man, came to know
that the whole range from Frank's Peak to

3219.text:
the Shoshone spurs was the proper domain of
a king well able to defend it, and the name

3225.text: of that king was Meteetsee Wahb.

3230.text:
Any creature whose strength puts him beyond
danger of open attack is apt to lose in cunning.

3237.text:
Yet Wahb never forgot his early experience
with the traps. He made it a rule never to

3244.text:
go near that smell of man and iron, and that
was the reason that he never again was caught.

3252.text:
So he led his lonely life and slouched around
on the mountains, throwing boulders about

3257.text:
like pebbles, and huge trunks like matchwood,
as he sought for his daily food. And every

3264.text:
beast of hill and plain soon came to know
and fly in fear of Wahb, the one time hunted,

3271.text:
persecuted Cub. And more than one Blackbear
paid with his life for the ill-deed of that

3277.text:
other, long ago. And many a cranky Bobcat
flying before him took to a tree, and if that

3284.text:
tree were dead and dry, Wahb heaved it down,
and tree and Cat alike were dashed to bits.

3293.text:
Even the proud-necked Stallion, leader of
the mustang band, thought well for once to

3299.text:
yield the road. The great, grey Timberwolves,
and the Mountain Lions too, left their new

3305.text:
kill and sneaked in sullen fear aside when
Wahb appeared. And if, as he hulked across

3312.text:
the sage-covered river-flat sending the scared
Antelope skimming like birds before him, he

3318.text:
was faced perchance, by some burly Range-bull,
too young to be wise and too big to be afraid,

3325.text:
Wahb smashed his skull with one blow of that
giant paw, and served him as the Range-cow

3331.text: would have served himself long years ago.

3336.text:
The All-mother never fails to offer to her
own, twin cups, one gall, and one of balm.

3345.text:
Little or much they may drink, but equally
of each. The mountain that is easy to descend

3351.text:
must soon be climbed again. The grinding hardship
of Wahb's early days had built his mighty

3357.text:
frame. All usual pleasures of a grizzly's
life had been denied him but _power_ bestowed

3368.text:
So he lived on year after year, unsoftened
by mate or companion, sullen, fearing nothing,

3375.text:
ready to fight, but asking only to be let
alone—quite alone. He had but one keen pleasure

3382.text:
in his sombre life—the lasting glory in
his matchless strength—the small but never

3388.text:
failing thrill of joy as the foe fell crushed
and limp, or the riven boulders grit and heaved

3395.text:
when he turned on them the measure of his
wondrous force.

3401.text:
Everything has a smell of its own for those
that have noses to smell. Wahb had been learning

3407.text:
smells all his life, and knew the meaning
of most of those in the mountains. It was

3412.text:
as though each and every thing had a voice
of its own for him; and yet it was far better

3418.text:
than a voice, for every one knows that a good
nose is better than eyes and ears together.

3424.text:
And each of these myriads of voices kept on
crying, "Here and such am I."

3431.text:
The juniper-berries, the rosehips, the strawberries,
each had a soft, sweet little voice, calling,

3439.text:
"Here we are—Berries, Berries."
The great pine woods had a loud, far-reaching

3445.text:
voice, "Here are we, the Pine-trees," but
when he got right up to them Wahb could hear

3452.text:
the low, sweet call of the piñon-nuts, "Here
are we, the Piñon-nuts."

3458.text:
And the quamash beds in May sang a perfect
chorus when the wind was right: "Quamash beds,

3464.text:
Quamash beds."
And when he got among them he made out each

3470.text:
single voice. Each root had its own little
piece to say to his nose: "Here am I, a big

3477.text:
Quamash, rich and ripe," or a tiny, sharp
voice, "Here am I, a good-for-nothing, stringy

3487.text:
And the broad, rich russulas in the autumn
called aloud, "I am a fat, wholesome Mushroom,"

3493.text:
and the deadly amanita cried, "I am an Amanita.
Let me alone, or you'll be a sick Bear." And

3502.text:
the fairy harebell of the cañon-banks sang
a song too, as fine as its thread-like stem,

3508.text:
and as soft as its dainty blue; but the warden
of the smells had learned to report it not,

3514.text:
for this, and a million other such, were of
no interest to Wahb.

3521.text:
So every living thing that moved, and every
flower that grew, and every rock and stone

3526.text:
and shape on earth told out its tale and sang
its little story to his nose. Day or night,

3534.text:
fog or bright, that great, moist nose told
him most of the things he needed to know,

3541.text:
or passed unnoticed those of no concern, and
he depended on it more and more. If his eyes

3548.text:
and ears together reported so and so, he would
not even then believe it until his nose said,

3554.text:
"Yes; that is right."
But this is something that man cannot understand,

3561.text:
for he has sold the birthright of his nose
for the privilege of living in towns.

3567.text:
While hundreds of smells were agreeable to
Wahb, thousands were indifferent to him, a

3573.text:
good many were unpleasant, and some actually
put him in a rage.

3579.text:
He had often noticed that if a west wind were
blowing when he was at the head of the Piney

3584.text:
Cañon there was an odd, new scent. Some days
he did not mind it, and some days it disgusted

3592.text:
him; but he never followed it up. On other
days a north wind from the high Divide brought

3597.text:
a most awful smell, something unlike any other,
a smell that he wanted only to get away from.

3608.text:
Wahb was getting well past his youth now,
and he began to have pains in the hind leg

3613.text:
that had been wounded so often. After a cold
night or a long time of wet weather he could

3619.text:
scarcely use that leg, and one day, while
thus crippled, the west wind came down the

3625.text:
cañon with an odd message to his nose. Wahb
could not clearly read the message, but it

3631.text:
seemed to say, "Come," and something within
him said, "Go." The smell of food will draw

3639.text:
a hungry creature and disgust a gorged one.
We do not know why, and all that any one can

3645.text:
learn is that the desire springs from a need
of the body. So Wahb felt drawn by what had

3651.text:
long disgusted him, and he slouched up the
mountain path, grumbling to himself and slapping

3658.text:
savagely back at branches that chanced to
switch his face.

3663.text:
The odd odor grew very strong; it led him
where he had never been before—up a bank

3670.text:
of whitish sand to a bench of the same color,
where there was unhealthy-looking water running

3676.text:
down, and a kind of fog coming out of a hole.
Wahb threw up his nose suspiciously—such

3684.text: a peculiar smell! He climbed the bench.

3689.text:
A snake wriggled across the sand in front.
Wahb crushed it with a blow that made the

3694.text:
near trees shiver and sent a balanced boulder
toppling down, and he growled a growl that

3700.text:
rumbled up the valley like distant thunder.
Then he came to the foggy hole. It was full

3708.text:
of water that moved gently and steamed. Wahb
put in his foot, and found it was quite warm

3715.text:
and that it felt pleasantly on his skin. He
put in both feet, and little by little went

3722.text:
in farther, causing the pool to overflow on
all sides, till he was lying at full length

3728.text:
in the warm, almost hot, sulphur-spring, and
sweltering in the greenish water, while the

3734.text: wind drifted the steam about overhead.

3739.text:
There are plenty of these sulphur-springs
in the Rockies, but this chanced to be the

3743.text:
only one on Wahb's range. He lay in it for
over an hour; then, feeling that he had had

3750.text:
enough, he heaved his huge bulk up on the
bank, and realized that he was feeling remarkably

3757.text:
well and supple. The stiffness of his hind
leg was gone.

3763.text:
He shook the water from his shaggy coat. A
broad ledge in full sun-heat invited him to

3769.text:
stretch himself out and dry. But first he
reared against the nearest tree and left a

3775.text:
mark that none could mistake. True, there
were plenty of signs of other animals using

3780.text:
the sulphur-bath for their ills; but what
of it? Thenceforth that tree bore this inscription,

3788.text:
in a language of mud, hair, and smell, that
every mountain creature could read:

3800.text:
Wahb lay on his belly till his back was dry,
then turned on his broad back and squirmed

3805.text:
about in a ponderous way till the broiling
sun had wholly dried him. He realized that

3811.text:
he was really feeling very well now. He did
not say to himself, "I am troubled with that

3816.text:
unpleasant disease called rheumatism, and
sulphur-bath treatment is the thing to cure

3821.text:
it." But what he did know was, "I have dreadful
pains; I feel better when I am in this stinking

3829.text:
pool." So thenceforth he came back whenever
the pains began again, and each time he was
