3849.text:
Years went by. Wahb grew no bigger,—there
was no need for that,—but he got whiter,

3856.text:
crosser, and more dangerous. He really had
an enormous range now. Each spring, after

3863.text:
the winter storms had removed his notice-boards,
he went around and renewed them. It was natural

3870.text:
to do so, for, first of all, the scarcity
of food compelled him to travel all over the

3876.text:
range. There were lots of clay wallows at
that season, and the itching of his skin,

3881.text:
as the winter coat began to shed, made the
dressing of cool, wet clay very pleasant,

3887.text:
and the exquisite pain of a good scratching
was one of the finest pleasures he knew. So,

3894.text:
whatever his motive, the result was the same:
the signs were renewed each spring.

3902.text:
At length the Palette Ranch outfit appeared
on the Lower Piney, and the men got acquainted

3907.text:
with the "ugly old fellow." The Cow-punchers,
when they saw him, decided they "hadn't lost

3914.text:
any Bears and they had better keep out of
his way and let him mind his business."

3918.text:
They did not often see him, although his tracks
and sign-boards were everywhere. But the owner

3925.text:
of this outfit, a born hunter, took a keen
interest in Wahb. He learned something of

3932.text:
the old Bear's history from Colonel Pickett,
and found out for himself more than the colonel

3937.text:
ever knew.
He learned that Wahb ranged as far south as

3942.text:
the Upper Wiggins Fork and north to the Stinking
Water, and from the Meteetsee to the Shoshones.

3950.text:
He found that Wahb knew more about Bear-traps
than most trappers do; that he either passed

3956.text:
them by or tore open the other end of the
bait-pen and dragged out the bait without

3961.text:
going near the trap, and by accident or design
Wahb sometimes sprang the trap with one of

3968.text:
the logs that formed the pen. This ranch-owner
found also that Wahb disappeared from his

3975.text:
range each year during the heat of the summer,
as completely as he did each winter during

3984.text:
Many years ago a wise government set aside
the head waters of the Yellowstone to be a

3990.text:
sanctuary of wildlife forever. In the limits
of this great Wonderland the ideal of the

3996.text:
Royal Singer was to be realized, and none
were to harm or make afraid. No violence was

4004.text:
to be offered to any bird or beast, no ax
was to be carried into its primitive forests,

4011.text:
and the streams were to flow on forever unpolluted
by mill or mine. All things were to bear witness

4018.text:
that such as this was the West before the
white man came.

4024.text:
The wild animals quickly found out all this.
They soon learned the boundaries of this unfenced

4030.text:
Park, and, as every one knows, they show a
different nature within its sacred limits.

4037.text:
They no longer shun the face of man, they
neither fear nor attack him, and they are

4043.text:
even more tolerant of one another in this
land of refuge.

4049.text:
Peace and plenty are the sum of earthly good;
so, finding them here, the wild creatures

4054.text:
crowd into the Park from the surrounding country
in numbers not elsewhere to be seen.

4061.text:
The Bears are especially numerous about the
Fountain Hotel. In the woods, a quarter of

4067.text:
a mile away, is a smooth open place where
the steward of the hotel has all the broken

4073.text:
and waste food put out daily for the Bears,
and the man whose work it is has become the

4079.text:
Steward of the Bears' Banquet. Each day it
is spread, and each year there are more Bears

4086.text:
to partake of it. It is a common thing now
to see a dozen Bears feasting there at one

4092.text:
time. They are of all kinds—Black, Brown,
Cinnamon, Grizzly, Silvertip, Roachbacks,

4100.text:
big and small, families and rangers, from
all parts of the vast surrounding country.

4106.text:
All seem to realize that in the Park no violence
is allowed, and the most ferocious of them

4113.text:
have here put on a new behavior. Although
scores of Bears roam about this choice resort,

4119.text:
and sometimes quarrel among themselves, not
one of them has ever yet harmed a man.

4126.text:
Year after year they have come and gone. The
passing travellers see them. The men of the

4132.text:
hotel know many of them well. They know that
they show up each summer during the short

4139.text:
season when the hotel is in use, and that
they disappear again, no man knowing whence

4144.text: they come or whither they go.

4147.text:
One day the owner of the Palette Ranch came
through the Park. During his stay at the Fountain

4153.text:
Hotel, he went to the Bear Banquet Hall at
high meal-tide. There were several Blackbears

4159.text:
feasting, but they made way for a huge Silvertip
Grizzly that came about sundown.

4166.text:
"That," said the man who was acting as guide,
"is the biggest Grizzly in the Park; but he

4172.text:
is a peaceable sort, or Lud knows what'd happen."
"That!" said the ranchman, in astonishment,

4180.text:
as the Grizzly came hulking nearer, and loomed
up like a load of hay among the piney pillars

4186.text:
of the Banquet Hall. "That! If that is not
Meteetsee Wahb, I never saw a Bear in my life!

4194.text:
Why, that is the worst Grizzly that ever rolled
a log in the Big Horn Basin."

4198.text:
"It ain't possible," said the other, "for
he's here every summer, July and August, an'

4206.text: I reckon he don't live so far away."

4208.text:
"Well, that settles it," said the ranchman;
"July and August is just the time we miss

4214.text:
him on the range; and you can see for yourself
that he is a little lame behind and has lost

4221.text:
a claw of his left front foot. Now I know
where he puts in his summers; but I did not

4228.text:
suppose that the old reprobate would know
enough to behave himself away from home."

4234.text:
The big Grizzly became very well known during
the successive hotel seasons. Once only did

4239.text:
he really behave ill, and that was the first
season he appeared, before he fully knew the

4247.text:
He wandered over to the hotel, one day, and
in at the front door. In the hall he reared

4254.text:
up his eight feet of stature as the guests
fled in terror; then he went into the clerk's

4259.text:
office. The man said: "All right; if you need
this office more than I do, you can have it,"

4267.text:
and leaping over the counter, locked himself
in the telegraph-office to wire the superintendent

4272.text:
of the Park: "Old Grizzly in the office now,
seems to want to run hotel; may we shoot?"

4279.text:
The reply came: "No shooting allowed in Park;
use the hose." Which they did, and, wholly

4287.text:
taken by surprise, the Bear leaped over the
counter too, and ambled out the back way,

4292.text:
with a heavy _thud-thudding_ of his feet,
and a rattling of his claws on the floor.

4298.text:
He passed through the kitchen as he went,
and, picking up a quarter of beef, took it

4303.text:
along.
This was the only time he was known to do

4308.text:
ill, though on one occasion he was led into
a breach of the peace by another Bear. This

4314.text:
was a large she-Blackbear and a noted mischief-maker.
She had a wretched, sickly cub that she was

4321.text:
very proud of—so proud that she went out
of her way to seek trouble on his behalf.

4329.text:
And he, like all spoiled children, was the
cause of much bad feeling. She was so big

4336.text:
and fierce that she could bully all the other
Blackbears, but when she tried to drive off

4341.text:
old Wahb she received a pat from his paw that
sent her tumbling like a football. He followed

4349.text:
her up, and would have killed her, for she
had broken the peace of the Park, but she

4354.text:
escaped by climbing a tree, from the top of
which her miserable little cub was apprehensively

4361.text:
squealing at the pitch of his voice. So the
affair was ended; in future the Blackbear

4367.text:
kept out of Wahb's way, and he won the reputation
of being a peaceable, well-behaved Bear. Most

4375.text:
persons believed that he came from some remote
mountains where were neither guns nor traps

4380.text: to make him sullen and revengeful.

4385.text:
Every one knows that a Bitter-root Grizzly
is a bad Bear. The Bitter-root Range is the

4391.text:
roughest part of the mountains. The ground
is everywhere cut up with deep ravines and

4397.text:
overgrown with dense and tangled underbrush.
It is an impossible country for horses, and

4403.text:
difficult for gunners, and there is any amount
of good Bear-pasture. So there are plenty

4409.text: of Bears and plenty of trappers.

4412.text:
The Roachbacks, as the Bitter-root Grizzlies
are called, are a cunning and desperate race.

4419.text:
An old Roachback knows more about traps than
half a dozen ordinary trappers; he knows more

4425.text:
about plants and roots than a whole college
of botanists. He can tell to a certainty just

4431.text:
when and where to find each kind of grub and
worm, and he knows by a whiff whether the

4439.text:
hunter on his trail a mile away is working
with guns, poison, dogs, traps, or all of

4445.text:
them together. And he has one general rule,
which is an endless puzzle to the hunter:

4453.text:
"Whatever you decide to do, do it quickly
and follow it right up." So when a trapper

4459.text:
and a Roachback meet, the Bear at once makes
up his mind to run away as hard as he can,

4465.text:
or to rush at the man and fight to a finish.
The Grizzlies of the Bad Lands did not do

4472.text:
this: they used to stand on their dignity
and growl like a thunder-storm, and so gave

4479.text:
the hunters a chance to play their deadly
lightning; and lightning is worse than thunder

4484.text:
any day. Men can get used to growls that rumble
along the ground and up one's legs to the

4491.text:
little house where one's courage lives; but
Bears cannot get used to 45-90 soft-nosed

4497.text:
bullets, and that is why the Grizzlies of
the Bad Lands were all killed off.

4504.text:
So the hunters have learned that they never
know what a Roachback will do; but they do

4509.text:
know that he is going to be quick about it.
Altogether these Bitter-root Grizzlies have

4515.text:
solved very well the problem of life, in spite
of white men, and are therefore increasing

4520.text:
in their own wild mountains.
Of course a range will hold only so many Bears,

4527.text:
and the increase is crowded out; so that when
that slim young Bald-faced Roachback found

4534.text:
he could not hold the range he wanted, he
went out perforce to seek his fortune in the

4541.text:
He was not a big Bear, or he would not have
been crowded out; but he had been trained

4546.text:
in a good school, so that he was cunning enough
to get on very well elsewhere. How he wandered

4554.text:
down to the Salmon River Mountains and did
not like them; how he traveled till he got

4558.text:
among the barbwire fences of the Snake Plains
and of course could not stay there; how a

4564.text:
mere chance turned him from going eastward
to the Park, where he might have rested; how

4571.text:
he made for the Snake River Mountains and
found more hunters than berries; how he crossed

4577.text:
into the Tetons and looked down with disgust
on the teeming man colony of Jackson's Hole,

4584.text:
does not belong to this history of Wahb. But
when Baldy Roachback crossed the Gros Ventre

4590.text:
Range and over the Wind River Divide to the
head of the Graybull, he does come into the

4596.text:
story, just as he did into the country and
the life of the Meteetsee Grizzly.

4603.text:
The Roachback had not found a man-sign since
he left Jackson's Hole, and here he was in

4610.text:
a land of plenty of food. He feasted on all
the delicacies of the season, and enjoyed

4616.text:
the easy, brushless country till he came on
one of Wahb's sign-posts.

4621.text:
"Trespassers beware!" it said in the plainest
manner. The Roachback reared up against it.

4630.text:
"Thunder! what a Bear!" The nose-mark was
a head and neck above Baldy's highest reach.

4638.text:
Now, a simple Bear would have gone quietly
away after this discovery; but Baldy felt

4644.text:
that the mountains owed him a living, and
here was a good one if he could keep out of

4649.text:
the way of the big fellow. He nosed about
the place, kept a sharp lookout for the present

4655.text:
owner, and went on feeding wherever he ran
across a good thing.

4661.text:
A step or two from this ominous tree was an
old pine stump. In the Bitter-roots there

4668.text:
are often mice-nests under such stumps, and
Baldy jerked it over to see. There was nothing.

4675.text:
The stump rolled over against the sign-post.
Baldy had not yet made up his mind about it;

4681.text:
but a new notion came into his cunning brain.
He turned his head on this side, then on that.

4689.text:
He looked at the stump, then at the sign,
with his little pig-like eyes. Then he deliberately

4696.text:
stood up on the pine root, with his back to
the tree, and put his mark away up, a head

4703.text:
at least above that of Wahb. He rubbed his
back long and hard, and he sought some mud

4710.text:
to smear his head and shoulders, then came
back and made the mark so big, so strong,

4717.text:
and so high, and emphasized it with such claw-gashes
in the bark, that it could be read only in

4724.text:
one way—a challenge to the present claimant
from some monstrous invader, who was ready,

4731.text:
nay anxious, to fight to a finish for this
desirable range.

4738.text:
Maybe it was accident and maybe design, but
when the Roachback jumped from the root it

4744.text:
rolled to one side. Baldy went on down the
cañon, keeping the keenest lookout for his

4751.text:
enemy.
It was not long before Wahb found the trail

4755.text:
of the interloper, and all the ferocity of
his outside-the-Park nature was aroused.

4762.text:
He followed the trail for miles on more than
one occasion. But the small Bear was quick-footed

4768.text:
as well as quick-witted, and never showed
himself. He made a point, however, of calling

4775.text:
at each sign-post, and if there was any means
of cheating, so that his mark might be put

4781.text:
higher, he did it with a vim, and left a big,
showy record. But if there was no chance for

4788.text:
any but a fair register, he would not go near
the tree, but looked for a fresh tree near

4793.text: by with some log or side-ledge to reach from.

4798.text:
Thus Wahb soon found the interloper's marks
towering far above his own—a monstrous Bear

4807.text:
evidently, that even he could not be sure
of mastering. But Wahb was no coward. He was

4814.text:
ready to fight to a finish anyone that might
come; and he hunted the range for that invader.

4820.text:
Day after day Wahb sought for him and held
himself ready to fight. He found his trail

4827.text:
daily, and more and more often he found that
towering record far above his own. He often

4834.text:
smelled him on the wind; but he never saw
him, for the old Grizzly's eyes had grown

4840.text:
very dim of late years; things but a little
way off were mere blurs to him. The continual

4847.text:
menace could not but fill Wahb with uneasiness,
for he was not young now, and his teeth and

4853.text:
claws were worn and blunted. He was more than
ever troubled with pains in his old wounds,

4861.text:
and though he could have risen on the spur
of the moment to fight any number of Grizzlies

4864.text:
of any size, still the continual apprehension,
the knowledge that he must hold himself ready

4871.text:
at any moment to fight this young monster,
weighed on his spirits and began to tell on

4880.text:
The Roachback's life was one of continual
vigilance, always ready to run, doubling and

4886.text:
shifting to avoid the encounter that must
mean instant death to him. Many a time from

4893.text:
some hiding-place he watched the great Bear,
and trembled lest the wind should betray him.

4899.text:
Several times his very impudence saved him,
and more than once he was nearly cornered

4905.text:
in a box-cañon. Once he escaped only by climbing
up a long crack in a cliff, which Wahb's huge

4913.text:
frame could not have entered. But still, in
a mad persistence, he kept on marking the

4924.text:
At last he scented and followed up the sulphur-bath.
He did not understand it at all. It had no

4931.text:
appeal to him, but hereabouts were the tracks
of the owner. In a spirit of mischief the

4937.text:
Roachback scratched dirt into the spring,
and then seeing the rubbing-tree, he stood

4943.text:
sidewise on the rocky ledge, and was thus
able to put his mark fully five feet above

4950.text:
that of Wahb. Then he nervously jumped down,
and was running about, defiling the bath and

4956.text:
keeping a sharp lookout, when he heard a noise
in the woods below. Instantly he was all alert.

4964.text:
The sound drew near, then the wind brought
the sure proof, and the Roachback, in terror,

4972.text: turned and fled into the woods.

4976.text:
It was Wahb. He had been failing in health
of late; his old pains were on him again,

4982.text:
and, as well as his hind leg, had seized his
right shoulder, where were still lodged two

4988.text:
rifle-balls. He was feeling very ill, and
crippled with pain. He came up the familiar

4995.text:
bank at a jerky limp, and there caught the
odor of the foe; then he saw the track in

5001.text:
the mud—his eyes said the track of a _small_
Bear, but his eyes were dim now, and his nose,

5009.text:
his unerring nose, said, "This is the track
of the huge invader." Then he noticed the

5017.text:
tree with his sign on it, and there beyond
doubt was the stranger's mark far above his

5023.text:
own. His eyes and nose were agreed on this;
and more, they told him that the foe was close

5030.text: at hand, might at any moment come.

5034.text:
Wahb was feeling ill and weak with pain. He
was in no mood for a desperate fight. A battle

5042.text:
against such odds would be madness now. So,
without taking the treatment, he turned and

5049.text:
swung along the bench away from the direction
taken by the stranger—the first time since

5055.text:
his cubhood that he had declined to fight.
That was a turning-point in Wahb's life. If

5062.text:
he had followed up the stranger he would have
found the miserable little craven trembling,

5067.text:
cowering, in an agony of terror, behind a
log in a natural trap, a walled-in glade only

5074.text:
fifty yards away, and would surely have crushed
him. Had he even taken the bath, his strength

5080.text:
and courage would have been renewed, and if
not, then at least in time he would have met

5085.text:
his foe, and his after life would have been
different. But he had turned. This was the

5092.text:
fork in the trail, but he had no means of
knowing it.

5097.text:
He limped along, skirting the lower spurs
of the Shoshones, and soon came on that horrid

5103.text:
smell that he had known for years, but never
followed up or understood. It was right in

5110.text:
his road, and he traced it to a small, barren
ravine that was strewn over with skeletons

5117.text:
and dark objects, and Wahb, as he passed,
smelled a smell of many different animals,

5124.text:
and knew by its quality that they were lying
dead in this treeless, grassless hollow. For

5130.text:
there was a cleft in the rocks at the upper
end, whence poured a deadly gas; invisible

5136.text:
but heavy, it filled the little gulch like
a brimming poison bowl, and at the lower end

5143.text:
there was a steady overflow. But Wahb knew
only that the air that poured from it as he

5148.text:
passed made him dizzy and sleepy, and repelled
him, so that he got quickly away from it and

5155.text:
was glad once more to breathe the piny wind.
Once Wahb decided to retreat, it was all too

5164.text:
easy to do so next time; and the result worked
double disaster. For, since the big stranger

5170.text:
was allowed possession of the sulphur-spring,
Wahb felt that he would rather not go there.

5177.text:
Sometimes when he came across the traces of
his foe, a spurt of his old courage would

5182.text:
come back. He would rumble that thunder-growl
as of old, and go painfully lumbering along

5189.text:
the trail to settle the thing right then and
there. But he never overtook the mysterious

5196.text:
giant, and his rheumatism, growing worse now
that he was barred from the cure, soon made

5202.text:
him daily less capable of either running or
fighting.

5208.text:
Sometimes Wahb would sense his foe's approach
when he was in a bad place for fighting, and,

5213.text:
without really running, he would yield to
a wish to be on a better footing, where he

5218.text:
would have a fair chance. This better footing
never led him nearer the enemy, for it is

5225.text:
well known that the one awaiting has the advantage.
Some days Wahb felt so ill that it would have

5232.text:
been madness to have staked everything on
a fight, and when he felt well or a little

5237.text: better, the stranger seemed to keep away.

5242.text:
Wahb soon found that the stranger's track
was most often on the Warhouse and the west

5247.text:
slope of the Piney, the very best feeding-grounds.
To avoid these when he did not feel equal

5253.text:
to fighting was only natural, and as he was
always in more or less pain now, it amounted

5260.text:
to abandoning to the stranger the best part
of the range.

5265.text:
Weeks went by. Wahb had meant to go back to
his bath, but he never did. His pains grew

5272.text:
worse; he was now crippled in his right shoulder
as well as in his hind leg.

5277.text:
The long strain of waiting for the fight begot
anxiety, that grew to be apprehension, which,

5284.text:
with the sapping of his strength, was breaking
down his courage, as it always must when courage

5290.text:
is founded on muscular force. His daily care
now was not to meet and fight the invader,

5297.text:
but to avoid him till he felt better.
Thus that first little retreat grew into one

5305.text:
long retreat. Wahb had to go farther and farther
down the Piney to avoid an encounter. He was

5313.text:
daily worse fed, and as the weeks went by
was daily less able to crush a foe.

5319.text:
He was living and hiding at last on the Lower
Piney—the very place where once his Mother

5325.text:
had brought him with his little brothers.
The life he led now was much like the one

5330.text:
he had led after that dark day. Perhaps for
the same reason. If he had had a family of

5337.text:
his own all might have been different. As
he limped along one morning, seeking among

5343.text:
the barren aspen groves for a few roots, or
the wormy partridge-berries that were too

5348.text:
poor to interest the Squirrel and the Grouse,
he heard a stone rattle down the western slope

5353.text:
into the woods, and, a little later, on the
wind was borne the dreaded taint. He waded

5360.text:
through the ice-cold Piney,—once he would
have leaped it,—and the chill water sent

5365.text:
through and up each great hairy limb keen
pains that seemed to reach his very life.

5373.text:
He was retreating again—which way? There
seemed but one way now—toward the new ranch-house.

5380.text:
But there were signs of stir about it long
before he was near enough to be seen. His

5388.text:
nose, his trustiest friend, said, "Turn, turn
and seek the hills," and turn he did even

5396.text:
at the risk of meeting there the dreadful
foe. He limped painfully along the north bank

5401.text:
of the Piney, keeping in the hollows and among
the trees. He tried to climb a cliff that

5407.text:
of old he had often bounded up at full speed.
When half-way up his footing gave way, and

5412.text:
down he rolled to the bottom. A long way round
was now the only road, for onward he must

5420.text:
go—on—on. But where? There seemed no choice
now but to abandon the whole range to the

5432.text:
And feeling, as far as a Bear can feel, that
he is fallen, defeated, dethroned at last,

5438.text:
that he is driven from his ancient range by
a Bear too strong for him to face, he turned

5444.text:
up the west fork, and the lot was drawn. The
strength and speed were gone from his once

5451.text:
mighty limbs; he took three times as long
as he once would to mount each well-known

5457.text:
ridge, and as he went he glanced backward
from time to time to know if he were pursued.

5463.text:
Away up the head of the little branch were
the Shoshones, bleak, forbidding; no enemies

5469.text:
were there, and the Park was beyond it all—on,
on he must go. But as he climbed with shaky

5477.text:
limbs, and short uncertain steps, the west
wind brought the odor of Death Gulch, that

5483.text:
fearful little valley where everything was
dead, where the very air was deadly. It used

5489.text:
to disgust him and drive him away, but now
Wahb felt that it had a message for him; he

5496.text:
was drawn by it. It was in his line of flight,
and he hobbled slowly toward the place. He

5504.text:
went nearer, nearer, until he stood upon the
entering ledge. A Vulture that had descended

5510.text:
to feed on one of the victims was slowly going
to sleep on the untouched carcass. Wahb swung

5518.text:
his great grizzled muzzle and his long white
beard in the wind. The odor that he once had

5524.text:
hated was attractive now. There was a strange
biting quality in the air. His body craved

5532.text:
it. For it seemed to numb his pain and it
promised sleep, as it did that day when first

5541.text:
Far below him, to the right and to the left
and on and on as far as the eye could reach,

5546.text:
was the great kingdom that once had been his:
where he had lived for years in the glory

5552.text:
of his strength; where none had dared to meet
him face to face. The whole earth could show

5558.text:
no view more beautiful. But Wahb had no thought
of its beauty; he only knew that it was a

5565.text:
good land to live in; that it had been his,
but that now it was gone, for his strength

5571.text:
was gone, and he was flying to seek a place
where he could rest and be at peace.

5579.text:
Away over the Shoshones, indeed, was the road
to the Park, but it was far, far away, with

5585.text:
a doubtful end to the long, doubtful journey.
But why so far? Here in this little gulch

5593.text:
was all he sought; here were peace and painless
sleep. He knew it; for his nose, his never-erring

5601.text:
nose, said, "_Here! here now!_"
He paused a moment at the gate, and as he

5610.text:
stood the wind-borne fumes began their subtle
work. Five were the faithful wardens of his

5616.text:
life, and the best and trustiest of them all
flung open wide the door he long had kept.

5622.text:
A moment still Wahb stood in doubt. His lifelong
guide was silent now, had given up his post.

5632.text:
But another sense he felt within. The Angel
of the Wild Things was standing there, beckoning,

5639.text:
in the little vale. Wahb did not understand.
He had no eyes to see the tear in the Angel's

5646.text:
eyes, nor the pitying smile that was surely
on his lips. He could not even see the Angel.

5657.text:
A rush of his ancient courage surged in the
Grizzly's rugged breast. He turned aside into

5664.text:
the little gulch. The deadly vapors entered
in, filled his huge chest and tingled in his

5670.text:
vast, heroic limbs as he calmly lay down on
the rocky, herbless floor and as gently went

5677.text:
to sleep, as he did that day in his Mother's
arms by the Graybull, long ago.

5688.text:
End of The Biography of a Grizzly
